As the biological mother of 2 daughters, (one of whom comments regularly), To NYT reader, Carolyn, please ponder: for starters, this all sounds very risky and complicated. Adoption may be quite $$$ and take a long time, but once it's done, both mother and adopted child would at least still be alive. Doesn't that count for something?

To the young lady in the article, who has 2 adopted children and wants the transplant because you want morning sickness: if you die, then what? You have wonderful family, already, who needs you. You want know morning sickness? If you've ever felt queasy, whether you vomited or not, trust me--there's your a.m. sickness. BTW, why would you want to go out of your way to feel miserable? Please think about it more; talk to some biological moms who experienced morning sickness & other discomforts which can accompany pregnancy. There must be a reason for the old saying that if men and women could alternate in the pregnancy business men would never go through with their second time "at bat."
Also consider untold, unpredictable birth defects w/ a baby consuming 9 months of anti-rejection drugs + side their effects--IF you & your baby survive the first trimester--side effects which kidney & heart recipients must cope with for basic survival. Talk to transplant recipients. They can give insight without vested interests, as can other moms.

Good luck & long life to you & yours!
